title: Are there stars without any orbiting planets? - Quora

response.answer_text: It is generally believed that planetary systems exist for all stars - with an exception. The exception is type 'O' and ‘B’ stars - the blue giants, that can be immensely powerful. It is believed that the radiation pressure and stellar wind emitted by such stars should be powerful enough to blow away any planet forming disks. Anyway, I do not think we currently have the technology to observe a star and conclude that it does not have a planet or planets orbiting it.

Current work indicates that 20% to 30% of stars don’t have planets that we can detect by current methods. These are however biased towards large planets and planets close to their star. A solar sytem with just planets equivalent in size and position of Neptune and Uranus wouldn’t show up yet. There are also very few that resemble out own solar system, though this again may be due to it being hard to detect. See 2016_08_130001 - other solar systems for more.

Yes surely. For once, first generation stars form from primeval clouds of hydrogen and helium, with no heavier elements around which could form planets. Binary systems are also strong candidates to not having planets since their orbits would be very unstable.
We used to think there were mostly stars without any orbiting planets. We were wrong. Now science estimates that every star has on average two planets.

Not that we can see. But there are 100 billion to 200 billion stars in our Galaxy, and we cannot see them closely enough to detect planets around many of them. The planets are simply much too small to ‘see’ or detect with the facilities at our disposal.
